article:
{{Infobox artwork| image_file=John Brack - The Bar.jpg
| backcolor=#FBF5DF painting_alignment=right image_size=300px title=The Bar
| artist=John Brack year=1954 type=oil on canvas height=96.4 width=140.0
| height_inch= width_inch = diameter_cm = diameter_inch = city=Melbourne
| museum=National Gallery of Victoria}}
'The Bar' is a 1954 painting by Australian artist John Brack. The subject of the
painting is a direct reference to Ãdouard Manet's 1882 work [[A Bar at the Folies-
BergÃ¨re]]. It depicts a barmaid working in an
Australian pub at the time of the "six o'clock swill". As in Manet's work, the
patrons of the bar are shown in a reflection behind the barmaid. The work is
considered a companion piece to Brack's later work [[Collins St., 5 pm]].

The painting was first sold to a Melbourne art collector for 90 guineas in
1954. In 2006, the painting sold for $3.12m, a then record
for an Australian work of art at auction. The National
Gallery of Victoria acquired the painting in 2009. 

The painting is part of the National Gallery of Victoria's Australian art
collection and exhibited in the Ian Potter Centre in Federation Square in
Melbourne.
categories: Paintings of the National Gallery of Victoria
